Award.AwardTitle: Enabling the Design of Failure-Tolerant Complex Engineered Systems using New Network-Based Modeling, Analysis, and Simulation Formalisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many engineered systems that form the fabric of our society, such as power grids, commercial aircraft, or self-driving cars, are by nature difficult to model and analyze. In such complex systems, many interacting subsystems are often independently designed, managed and engineered. This "design-by-subsystem" approach reduces the cost and complexity of the design process, but prevents the discovery of unexpected, emergent interactions between subsystems until the system is integrated and tested in operation. This award explores new methods of failure analysis for complex engineered systems by focusing on how the failure modes depend on the connections between subsystems and the variables and parameters governing the physics-based behaviors of those subsystems. While in previous research network models of complex engineered systems have been introduced to address this issue, the fundamental limitation remains the exclusive reliance on physical and functional dependencies between components. This research aims to produce a set of indicators to assist engineers in quantifying the failure tolerance of complex engineered systems without going through the expense of a complete system simulation, which in many cases is neither feasible nor practical.

This project specifically introduces a new approach to robust design based on failure tolerance of interdependent networks. The approach explicitly addresses both physical architecture and behavioral, physics-based relations as contributing to the system's tolerance to failure. The methodology incorporates a mesoscale property of complex networks, namely modularity, to understand how the architecture of components and their physics-based relations have an important function of creating stability and failure tolerance. The project will first introduce a new conceptualization of robust design based upon the relational stability between design elements. This represents an important conceptual shift in thinking about robust design, moving away from component reliability alone towards consideration of the connectivity of the behavior of parts. The project will then introduce a network-based methodology and simulation environment capable of calculating the robustness of a complex engineered system. A set of measures will be introduced, which, while being single quantities, holistically capture the failure behavior of the complex engineered system not just at phase transition between nominal behavior and failure but before and after that as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigates the use of network-based formalisms in enabling the design of robust complex engineered systems. This work re-conceptualizes robustness in complex engineered systems using the principle of network attack, in which removal of one node in a network is analogous to a fault in a component, function, or parameter in the complex engineered system, and spreading epidemic, in which the transmission of undesirable material (e.g., detritus) or energy (e.g. vibration) reduces or damages the performance of the system. This new conceptualization enables the assessment of robustness without complete, high fidelity mathematical models and computational simulations, meaning engineering designers can assess robustness early in the design process before such models are available. Additionally, due to the gains in computational efficiency, large-scale systems can be analyzed in their entirety, rather than in modules, enabling improved consideration of emergent behaviors. Specific objectives include: (1) producing methods for modeling systems with software and physical components, (2) introducing formalisms for representing failure modes of complex engineered systems, (3) identifying metrics and methods for assessing the robustness of complex engineered systems, and (4) investigating ways of rearchitecting systems to improve robustness. In addressing these objectives, we introduced novel network-based approaches for modeling complex engineered systems, including software components with logical and embedded behavior, from physical/architectural, functional, and behavioral perspectives. Moreover, we introduced a method for capturing failures using network-based metrics and tools. We have identified network metrics, including average shortest path length and robustness coefficient, for assessing system robustness and tested them using both synthetic networks as well as a number of real-world network-based models of complex engineered systems such as a commercial turbofan jet engine. We have investigated modularity as a design rule and discovered trade-offs between modularity and robustness, both to single point failures and to cascading failures. These advances will lead to the adoption of network-based methods for assessing the robustness of complex engineered systems within our field. Finally, we discovered structural patterns in systems dynamics models of complex engineered systems that are related to the occurrence of unintended consequences. More broadly, this research provides metrics and methods that can be used to inform robustness analysis in the early stages of the design process. These advances will ultimately lead to safer, more effective complex engineered systems at a lower cost.
